intro: Ranunculus kossuthii, commonly known as the Hungarian buttercup, is a perennial herbaceous plant native to the Carpathian Basin. It typically grows in moist meadows and along stream banks, preferring well-drained, loamy soils. The plant features compound leaves with three leaflets and produces showy yellow flowers with prominent white markings. It is part of the Ranunculaceae family, known for its often toxic compounds. Ranunculus kossuthii is valued for its ornamental appeal and ecological importance in its native habitat.
